query: Who is Bassim Haider and what role did he play in this dispute?
hypothesis: Bassim Haidar's identity, role, and connection to Channel IT as the owner/beneficial owner of Gulfstream G550, SN 5174, are not supported by the current search results. While 'the aircraft owner' is frequently referenced, Bassim Haidar is not named, nor are Channel IT or any specific communications from him/them. Danny Farnham appears as a key representative or expert witness for the owner/dispute, and AVCON acted on the owner's behalf to initiate the maintenance request.
final_output:
**TO:** Senior Partner
**FROM:** [Your Name]
**DATE:** October 26, 2023
**RE:** Role of Bassim Haidar in Channel IT v. Gulfstream Aerospace Dispute

***

## **MEMORANDUM OF LAW**

### I. Executive Summary

Bassim Haidar is the beneficial owner of the Gulfstream G550, SN 5174 (the "Aircraft") at the center of this dispute, holding ownership through his corporation, Channel IT Isle of Man Limited ("CITIOM"). Mr. Haidar played a direct and active role in the dispute by personally communicating his frustrations regarding significant maintenance delays and cost overruns to senior Gulfstream executives. The evidence gathered directly refutes the initial working hypothesis that his connection to the matter was unsupported.

### II. Factual Background

In late 2018, CITIOM, a corporation owned by high-net-worth individual Bassim Haidar, acquired the Gulfstream G550, SN 5174 [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 5]. The Aircraft had previously undergone a 144-month inspection by the Gulfstream Savannah Service Center between April and July 2020 [EXPERT WITNESS REPORT March 5 (1).docx, p. 1] [UNVERIFIED].

The current dispute originates from a subsequent 192-month major structural inspection. Gulfstream provided a proposal for this work, which CITIOM accepted through its aircraft management company, Avcon Jet, A.G. ("Avcon Jet") [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 5]. This proposal stated that cost and downtime estimates were for inspection tasks only and explicitly excluded the cost or time associated with correcting any discovered discrepancies [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 2].

During the inspection, Gulfstream discovered significant corrosion, leading to a substantial increase in labor hours, from an original estimate of approximately 2,800 man-hours to a final total exceeding 27,000 hours [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 5], [CITIOM Amended Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 4]. This resulted in an 11-month maintenance period [111-206.pdf, p. 4] [UNVERIFIED].

Mr. Haidar became personally involved as the delays and costs mounted. Around March 2024, he communicated directly with Gulfstream representatives, including Murtaza Hassan, expressing frustration that costs had escalated to "almost 3 times more" than an original quote of '1.6m' [Evidence Bullet Point]. On March 15, 2024, Mr. Haidar was also involved in a letter of intent for the sale of the Aircraft, underscoring the commercial impact of the delays [3. CITIOM Resp and Obj to Gulfstream RFPs.pdf, p. 6] [UNVERIFIED].

His involvement escalated on August 13, 2024, when he forwarded an email to Gulfstream executive Mark Burns, stating, "11 months for a 192 check and we are struggling to get my aircraft back. This is unbelievable" [111-206.pdf, p. 4] [UNVERIFIED]. This communication prompted an internal response within Gulfstream, with Mr. Burns directing Derek Zimmerman to draft a reply [Evidence Bullet Point]. Direct correspondence between Mr. Zimmerman and Mr. Haidar is also documented as of April 30, 2024 [CITIOM Amended Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3].

### III. Analysis

#### A. Key Findings

1.  **Beneficial Owner:** Bassim Haidar is the ultimate beneficial owner of the Aircraft through his company, CITIOM, the Claimant in this matter [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 5].
2.  **Direct Communication:** Mr. Haidar personally and directly engaged with senior Gulfstream executives, including Mark Burns and Derek Zimmerman, to escalate his complaints regarding the maintenance project [CITIOM Amended Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3], [111-206.pdf, p. 3] [UNVERIFIED].
3.  **Active Role in Dispute:** Mr. Haidar’s role was not passive. He actively voiced his concerns over the core issues of the dispute: the extended downtime of 11 months, escalating costs, and alleged manpower issues at the Gulfstream facility [207-329.pdf, p. 2] [UNVERIFIED], [111-206.pdf, p. 4] [UNVERIFIED].
4.  **Central Witness:** Claimant’s counsel intends to use Mr. Haidar as a key witness to "humanize the case," demonstrate reliance on Gulfstream's representations, and testify to the business impact caused by the delays, including interference with a planned resale of the Aircraft [Full Direct List.docx, p. 1] [UNVERIFIED].

#### B. Supporting Evidence

The strongest evidence establishing Mr. Haidar’s identity and role comes from verified filings by both parties. Gulfstream's Prehearing Brief explicitly identifies CITIOM as "a corporation owned by a high-net worth individual, Bassim Haider" and the "registered owner of the Aircraft" [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 5]. CITIOM’s Amended Statement of Claim references direct email correspondence between Gulfstream’s Mr. Zimmerman and Mr. Haidar [CITIOM Amended Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3].

Numerous (though unverified) documents corroborate his active role. Emails show his direct address (`bassim.haidar@channelit.net`) in communications with Gulfstream personnel regarding "G550, SN 5174" [111-206.pdf, p. 3] [UNVERIFIED], [207-329.pdf, p. 11] [UNVERIFIED]. His message to Mark Burns on August 13, 2024, is a critical piece of evidence demonstrating his personal frustration and direct escalation [111-206.pdf, p. 4] [UNVERIFIED]. Gulfstream’s internal response to that email further solidifies his position as the client representative they needed to address directly [207-329.pdf, p. 2] [UNVERIFIED].

#### C. Contradictions or Concerns

The evidence gathered directly refutes the initial Working Hypothesis, which stated that Mr. Haidar's identity, role, and connection to CITIOM were unsupported by search results. The available documents conclusively establish his central role as the beneficial owner and a key actor in the dispute. There are no material contradictions within the body of evidence itself.

#### D. Evidence Strength Assessment

**Strong.**

The evidence establishing Mr. Haidar's identity and central role is strong. This assessment is based on affirmations in verified legal filings from both parties in the dispute [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 5], [CITIOM Amended Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3]. This foundational evidence is further reinforced by a consistent and substantial body of unverified documentary evidence, primarily direct email correspondence, that details his personal involvement.

### IV. Entities & Relationships

*   **Bassim Haidar:** A high-net-worth individual; the beneficial owner of the Aircraft and the sole owner of CITIOM. He acted as the ultimate client representative in communications with Gulfstream.
*   **Channel IT Isle of Man Limited (CITIOM):** The Claimant; a corporation owned by Mr. Haidar and the registered owner of the Aircraft.
*   **Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation:** The Respondent; the maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) service provider.
*   **Avcon Jet, A.G.:** An aircraft management company retained by CITIOM to arrange the maintenance visit and execute the initial proposal on its behalf.
*   **Danny Farnham:** CITIOM's onsite representative during the maintenance visit and designated expert witness.

### V. Gaps & Limitations

*   **Evidence Not Found:** Full, native email chains are not present; the record consists of excerpts, forwards, and references to these communications. The initial proposal and final invoice, which would detail the specific cost discrepancies, have not been fully analyzed.
*   **Areas for Further Investigation:** The precise contractual relationship between CITIOM, Avcon Jet, and Gulfstream should be clarified. The full context of the high-level communications between Mr. Haidar and Gulfstream executives requires further exploration to understand what promises or representations may have been made.
*   **Limitations of Documents:** The primary limitation is the high number of unverified documents. While their content is consistent, verification is required before they can be fully relied upon in an evidentiary capacity.

### VI. Recommendations

1.  **Immediate Actions:** Prioritize the deposition of Bassim Haidar to secure his testimony regarding his direct communications with Gulfstream, his reliance on their initial quotes and timelines, and the specific business damages incurred due to the project's delays, including the impact on the planned sale of the Aircraft.
2.  **Additional Investigation:**
    *   Serve Requests for Production to obtain native copies of all email correspondence referenced in this memo between Mr. Haidar and Gulfstream personnel.
    *   Verify the authenticity of all currently unverified documents, particularly the expert witness report by Danny Farnham and the direct emails from Mr. Haidar.
3.  **Risk Mitigation:** Given that Claimant's strategy is to "humanize the case" through Mr. Haidar's testimony [Full Direct List.docx, p. 1] [UNVERIFIED], our legal strategy must anticipate a narrative focused on emotional and business frustration. Cross-examination should be prepared to redirect focus to the contractual terms, specifically the written disclaimers in the initial proposal regarding unforeseen discrepancies, and the role of CITIOM’s own representatives (Avcon Jet, Danny Farnham) in managing the project.

Under Georgia law, when a contract is silent on time limits, a 'reasonable time' for performance is implied.
Contractual limitations on damages are generally valid under Georgia law, unless they purport to relieve liability for gross negligence or willful/wanton conduct.

The dispute centers on a Gulfstream G550 aircraft, Serial Number (SN) 5174, undergoing a 192-month inspection at a Gulfstream Service Center.
AVCON contacted Gulfstream in May 2023, on behalf of the aircraft owner, to request a quote for the upcoming 192-month inspection for SN 5174, and approved the proposal in September 2023.

Danny Farnham is an individual who actively expressed concern and disappointment regarding manpower issues on the SN 5174 project and challenged Gulfstream on maintenance items, such as engine mounts.
Gulfstream failed to conduct adequate pre-proposal assessment of SN 5174's history, leading to unrealistic expectations for the aircraft owner regarding cost and downtime.

Engine mount assemblies for SN 5174, initially deemed scrap due to illegible identification, were ultimately replaced by Gulfstream at no charge after the issue was challenged (resolved September 26, 2024).
The subject of the dispute is a Gulfstream G550, SN 5174, OE-LIM.
Concerns and dissatisfaction are expressed regarding the efficiency and level of service during the inspection project.
A crucial part, WTBF Frame PN 1159B51246-39, is unavailable, pushing the RTS to January 6th, 2025.
Issues also arise with the left hand floor beam angle cap, with its replacement causing further delays and unclear justification for added project time.
Communication issues are cited, including a lack of information on holiday schedules and deputy availability, and insufficient updates from Gulfstream.
The on-site representative, Danny (from Gulfstream), is identified as the primary source of information regarding project progress.
Parts sent out for repair have not yielded timely updates, requiring direct follow-up.
AVCON JET AG values a collaborative approach and believes improved options and clearer communication would enhance project progress.
An Aircraft Purchase Agreement draft is mentioned and being reviewed.
A Letter of Intent (LOI) for the aircraft has been accepted and signed by the seller.
Mr. Bassim Haidar, Chairman, Founder & CEO of Channel IT Isle of Man Ltd, is addressed in correspondence from Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation.
Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, through Mark Burns (President), is responding to concerns raised by Mr. Bassim Haidar regarding an ongoing maintenance event.
The maintenance event involves Gulfstream G550, serial number 5174.
Original work order quote estimated 2800 manhours, but discrepancies added an estimated 20,000 additional manhours.
Estimated completion date is projected for mid-November, subject to engineering evaluations of corrosion.
Mr. Eunan Timmins, Director of Channel IT Isle of Man Limited, also received correspondence from Gulfstream regarding the same aircraft maintenance event.

under each inspection line item in Section I of the proposal (Workscope Description), the proposal states that the “correction of discrepancies is not included in the quoted price.” That statement appears ten separate times in Section I.
